label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, January 7, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding how much she misses Sidney and wishes she could join him in Hawaii. She goes on to discuss Sidney and Morris’s social life on the island and discuss the war in Africa.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
54
Jan 7th '43
Dear Sidney,
" Sunshine, laughter and white beaches"! Let that be our slogan.
The outrigger club sounds heaven for you. Absolutely perfect. Please describe
it some more. How big is it? Where is it? who uses it? How many people do you
find there of an evening? Do you sit and eat in bathing suits? Are there flowers a
on the tables? Do you smell ginger and guardenias? My I want to go there, I want to
lie on the white sand beside you, watch the l[i]ttle white waves beat up on the beach.
Watch the sunset pink on the horizon, sea the palm[s]glisten in the moonlight, hear
hawaian music drift across the soft nightair. It kills me my darling. I want to
be there with you so much. I am so happy for you both being able to enjoyit, to be
living the way you describe instead of worring about you- if you were at sea, chased
by submarines, or on Guadacanal, or flying in bombers or a million otherupsetting
things that would really drive me frantic with worry. It is so wonderful my darling
to know you two are together, happy and well[,]and able to laugh and swim, tennis.
Pleasewhen this ends lets live that sort of life together. I have always loved it
so. Its so beautiful, so simple so close to what really counts, the earth, the sky,
the sea, the sunsets.
This city is purgatory pure and simple. The crowds, the noise, the dead
grey grim atmosphere. The empty life, the man made horrors of stone and cement.
No beauty, no nature, no color no nothing.
Are you quite sure you have tried and KNOW that it is impossible to ask
for me to come out?
[End Page 1]
2
If you think you are going to be pretty permenently I should
think there would be a way.
I am sorry Darling you have lost an other tennis player. You have not mentioned
playing tennis at all[,]and I did not even know that you had games any more. In
fact you never mention anybody- men or women and it always gives me a picture
of you and Morris just alw[a]ys together seeing no one. I am sure that is a wrong
picture but the one you have given me neverthe less. [except for your Xmas dinner.]
I can see your desks now in the dark hall.It sounds as bleak as mine. I can
not picture where your apartmwnt it[,]or where the Outrigger Club is[,]or how farone
is from the other.
I am so glad vitamin pills have cured the old man and broughthim backto act[i]ve
life with you again. I am sure it will be fun now with him up and around and
bathing with you once more. Dining at the club and eating all that good food sound[s]
so heavenly. I suppose you do it every night now. I shouldt[h]ink youwould. Do you
meet attractive peo[p]le there? Do you sit on a terrace, are there cabanas?
Please darling take some photographs for me. I long to see you and see your heaven[ly]
setting out there in the tropics. Nothing could make me possibl[y] more green with 
envy or giving me a greater pang in the heart than to be here when we might be
leading that perfect life together. How nice if when our jobs ended at 6 we could
go hand in hand to the Outrigger Club and laugh and swim together. It urst
terribly not to be there. It is really agony my darling I mis[s]you so much. It
does not get easier as time goes on.I find it harder and harder.
Gasolene I know is a small drop in the bucket as far as importence goes I know[,]
but neverthe less the new rule has gone into effect that no driving is allowed
any more for social reasons. Only can be used to and from work. No more can I
dine out in the station wagon. I walk, attempt to find a taxi or stay home. The
busses are now so deep you cant get on them. 60 people will be standing up inside
then. I
[End Page 2]
3
What you eat for dinner now depends entirely on what you can get. My cook
agrees to only work eight hours a day for 20 dollars a week so she goes home
at seven[,]and I arrive home at eight. Well all such things are trivial I know
in the face of a war, in the face of the suffering that is going on etc.
I would n't mind anything. I would be quite happy to live on coacoanuts for t
the rest of my life if I were with you. One needs so little when one is in
a climate where the air is soft and one can live in a bathing suit. One spends
so little, one has no desire to buy anything. Its the simplicity that I long
for with you. No more of those worries when you lock your self up in the
office for hours to work over the books, the farm accounts, the repair budgets
and the like.I dont believe one has to be involved like that.You and I have a
always been so happy doing the simple things, Portofino, the little house in
Paris,St Jean, the little cages on the squaire,motoring with tennis racquets
to Bastaad, eating an omlet and salad on a checkered cloth in some tiny french
village. The simple things are always the pleasantest.I want to live by the sea
and enjoy all the heavenly descriptions that you picture to me in your letters.
I hope that if and when the war is over we may be allowed to laugh and love
and live on a beach together.
The war in Africa is not very bright and again to me the war looks
long... str[e]tching out ahead for many months and months to come. It is an
upsetting world, a dislocated world[,]and a world that will be hard to adjust
itself again to normal living. The post War world will be tough but I dont care
how tough if I can have you in it beside me my darling.
Please telephone me. I would not know when to call you now as
I would probably call when you are at the Outrigger Club. Maybe you ad better
give me the number of the outrigger Club[,]or else do what I suggested telephone
me[,]and reverse the call. Please reverse the call however because those phone
calls are expensive and it would eliminate your salary check as thought it were
made of steam. 
I hope you take no courses on anything so you wont get sent away
like that tennis partner of yours in fourty seconds. I think if you two are
good executive administrators[,]tha[t] you would be so missed that they could not
afford to let you goI Dont you think so? Have you heard any rumors to the
contrary? I do hope not.
Your letters are wonderful sweetheart and I love each and every
one[,]and read them over and over again.
Dont forget to send me some snapshots.
Lots of love to you sweet heart.Pretend those little waves 
on the beach come all the way from America with love to caress your
sweet ears. My I would give a million million million dollars and all the
sugar plums in the world to see you, to touch you, to kiss you with a bigg
big hug and hold you tight tight .
Your-
Gertie.
[End Page 3]
